reviewText:
Early Access Review

DvDrum is a drum simulator where you played it with keyboard (I haven't try it using other devices).
The improvement in this Steam version is really good from previous non-Steam version, especially at saving and loading your own keymap, soundset, and drum kit. (If you are non-Steam DvDrum user, you know that feel)

Personally, I think the main focus on this game" is customization.
You can customize your desired keymap for your controller
date: customize your drum kit that will be displayed
recommended: and also customize the sound set of the drum that included in-game sound mixer (screenshot provided in Store Page).\n\nThis game is good for practicing drum
voteText: you can set your metronome so you can practice at your tempo while you drumming.\n-Embed music
votesHelpful: you can add a music in game and played it on background. Perhaps you want to practice covering some song? (Beware
votesFunny: some song is too hard to cover)\n\nOther than that
commentsCount: the in-game drum sound is so great.\nAlso
column16:
MAY causing lag in the "game" window when you played and/or recorded it with video recorder software. Be sure to close unnecessary background process.

And here's my personal feedback/suggest:
More simplified the UI (Also

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Well why would you pay 13 euros instead of downloading and setting up some free DAW with some free drums VST? That way you could actually learn how to create music on your computer.
And this shouldn't cost more than 3, maybe 4 euros.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I really like this. The only thing that may turn people away is that the game looks like a crumby java game. Hope they update the interface to look better. I'd also like it if they would remove that rock music at the beginning. I don't have anything against rock; I just find it out of place.

This game actually has tons of options. It's great! You can fully customize your drumb kit. There's even a record option in the game, so you can create some nice music with this. ;)
voteText: 16 of 23 people (70%) found this review helpful 3 people found this review funny

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Full disclosure: So when I first saw this game on steam I thought: WTF is this.
So I got it (from a bundle) just so I could find out what it is and to make this review.

First of. I play drums for hobby. And have done so for years.
Meanwhile I've also accumulated a huge collection of audio software (VST, DAW, fx, etc) and misc instruments.

Review: Is this a game or music software?
Short answer is neither.

For a game there is no actual gameplay. And is therefore classified as a “simulator”.

And for a virtual instrument (VST) it perform very bad. Focusing more on the visuals of the drums rather than the sound.
I have yet to try and use DvDrum with any of my midi instruments and controllers.

If you want to make music. Then you are better off buying something else. Such as EzDrummer which is cheap, and easy to use.
Do not BUY.
There are better options for free..

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nReally great product honestly i just tested my ps3 drum set on it and it responds really well. The sound is good, and i can even use multiple drumsets for more drums and have a full set. Great way to save 1600 dollars on a drum set and keep space in your apartment!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Looking pretty good already!
Have some trouble trying to get my digital drumkit (KAT KT3) to work on it, so I hope a future update will bring midi support.
I also think the graphics could be a lot sleeker, some people might find the interface too cartoony.

I did play around on it, and the sounds are pretty good! I'd even say close to proffessional VSTI's like Superior Drummer and EZ Drummer.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Utterly useless.
To play along to drumless songs" the program opens your web browser and navigates to their site where you can play audio files by clicking on them. It's completely not integrated into the actual program. What's more
date: the "drumless" audio tracks are not drumless at all but just clumsily filtered tracks to reduce the volume of the drums a bit. Also
recommended: given the fame of the bands they are using I can't imagine they actually have permission to use these tracks: Blur
helpfulPercent: Beastie Boys etc. There's just no way they are doing this legally.\n\nSimilarly
votesHelpful: the recording features are not in the program itself: instead you can set the program to launch an external exe to record video or sound.\n\nThen we have the quality of the program itself
column16: bad. You can select different samples for each drum but once you have selected one
column17: that's it: you will get the exact same sample played at the exact same volume every time you trigger it.\n\nYou can play the drums with your computer keyboard or by clicking on them with your mouse. The mouse clicking is massively inaccurate: there are tons of places you can click on the drum and nothing happens. As far as I can tell you can't use a midi keyboard or other device like launchpad
column18: maschine etc.\n\nThe mixer has terribly unintuitive controls: instead of clicking and dragging to set the on-screen pots you have to left click on the pot to select it and then use the scroll wheel to set it
column19: then click left again to exit!\n\nThis program is utter garbage. It does next to nothing and what it does do

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nDon't let the videos deceive you.  Not saying this isn't a good drum simulator but that is pretty much all it is.  You have to train your fingers just as much as you would have to train yourself playing an actual drum kit.  Its not easy and most of the options in the video are not accessible.  It is very eary access.  For now I do not recommend this unless you are just looking to bang around some virtual drums and practice for fun or to just goof around.
